title: Grey seal

content.title: External appearance
content.content: The largest of the Baltic Sea seals. Females are smaller than males. Weighs 100–310 kg. Coat colour can vary, but grey predominates.

content.title: Distribution
content.content: Found in the North Atlantic. Mainly found around islands. In summer they haul out on shore, in winter – on the ice.

content.title: Diet
content.content: Seals hunt for fish in the water: cod, flounder, herring, salmon; less frequently – crustaceans and molluscs.

content.title: Development
content.content: Baltic grey seals usually give birth to pups on the ice in February and March. If there is no ice, they will give birth on shore or on islands.

content.title: Hunting
content.content: Seals were once hunted intensively, mainly for their blubber and fur, which led to a sharp decline in numbers in the early 20 th century.

fact:
Adults can stay underwater for more than ten minutes. The white, fluffy coat
of pups is not waterproof.
